title: Fundies warn Lowe that low rates are backfiring
text:
The fund managers who wrote to the Reserve Bank of Australia urging it to consider the destructive consequences of low interest rates, have repeated their plea to governor Philip Lowe, saying quality Australian businesses are suffering because low rates allow even the most inefficient companies to survive and compete.

Investors Mutual investment director Anton Tagliaferro and senior portfolio manager Hugh Giddy said their worst fears about low rates have come true, and decent companies were sacking staff and scrambling to cut costs in order to level the playing field.

They also dispute there has been any pay-off for growth from Australia's record low 0.75 per cent cash rate. Financial markets expect at least another reduction from the Reserve Bank, but not until February 2020, and the possibility of unconventional monetary stimulus is now being discussed.

"Unfortunately, many of these unintended consequences have come to pass, including slowing economic growth, increased borrowing among consumers and companies, and rising competition among businesses as inefficient companies remain afloat longer than they might have without the lifeline of cheap debt – forcing solid, established businesses to retrench workers or take other cost-cutting measures in order to compete," the fund managers wrote on Tuesday.

They asked the governor in 2016, when the cash rate was 1.5 per cent, to consider that low rates were a form of punishment for retirees and rewarded reckless risk-taking.
description: "If low interest rates and ease of borrowing were the foundation of strong growth, surely Japan and Europe would now be growing very strongly," Investors Mutual says.
